utterance.speaker: Announcer
utterance.content: As the riders begin lap 2, Jeff Forster is leading the pack.

utterance.speaker: Kid 1
utterance.content: This is so cool!

utterance.speaker: Kid 2
utterance.content: Did we miss anything?

utterance.speaker: Kid 1
utterance.content: They've got like 11 laps to go

utterance.speaker: Kid 2
utterance.content: We've got to find a good place where he can see the sign as he goes by

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Wait up kids!

utterance.speaker: Kid 1
utterance.content: Turn 6! Come on!

utterance.speaker: Kid 1
utterance.content: That's it! Up there!

utterance.speaker: Kid 2
utterance.content: Can you see anything?

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Did you bring his inhaler?

utterance.speaker: Dad
utterance.content: Oh crap, it’s in the car. I'll go get it.

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Are you ok? Your dad's going to be right--

utterance.speaker: Kid 2
utterance.content: I can see him, he's right up front!

utterance.speaker: Mom
utterance.content: Honey, you're wheezing!

utterance.speaker: Kid 2
utterance.content: Here they come!

utterance.speaker: Kid 1
utterance.content: Go Jeff! Yeah!

utterance.speaker: Kid 2
utterance.content: You're number one!

utterance.speaker: Kid 1
utterance.content: He doesn't look so good.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah!

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: We need to talk.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh god. Are you pregnant? ‘Cause I really want to finish high school

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: You have to renew your credentials!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They're good for two more months

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: Three weeks. The paperwork takes forever. Your application, your malpractice insurance, criminal records check - you know that’s going to take some explaining

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You know; our relationship was way better when we were sleeping together. Why'd we stop doing that? Did you get married?

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: Yeah! Otherwise I'd be on you like red on rice

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Rice isn’t r— Oh I get it!

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: You're also behind on your dictations

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don't do dictations. Cameron does them, or somebody.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: You can't have your sole female employee doing your clerical work which you'd know if you'd attended the required sexual harassment seminars. Then I'm going to pause so you can make a crack about harassment.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Joke killer

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: House, got a patient

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sorry, can't play anymore, my mom's calling me

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: We just admitted a world class cyclist

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’ve got to fire Stacy

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Yeah I'll get right on that . Jeff Forster, respiratory arrest at 30 miles per hour.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She's loading me up with pointless paperwork

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Didn't know you were behind on your pointless paperwork. O2 stats are in the--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She's hostile. You know me, hostility makes me shrink up like a... can't think of a non-sexual metaphor. She's going to stand over my desk with a ruler checking my spelling!

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: ER checked for lung infiltrates, nothing there

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Professional athletes, Cuddy! It's like watching an old movie at 2am, re-living all the classic moments. Part where he denies it's drugs, part where the good guys ride in, tests a-blazing, prove that it IS drugs. Oscar clip, he can't imagine how that got into his body! So familiar, so comforting. She can't handle working with me

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Oh right, yeah, she's still got a thing for you, making it impossible for her to deal, makes perfect sense. Except for the pronouns!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Anyway, thanks for getting me out of that meeting.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He's not denying the drugs.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I'm thinking he's actually sick.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Jeff Forster, this is Dr--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm a doctor, you're a sick person. And you are a loved one

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: Actually, Manager. We've been together for seven years

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So what's the drug du jour on the bike circuit these days? Still erythropoietin? Or are you guys just chugging battery acid?

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: There's no way I'd touch EPO. Too many guys stroking out and dying.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Damn! Ten bucks for the tickets, six for the popcorn

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: I do straight blood doping.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Plot twist!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's a very daring confession

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: We've got confidentiality, right?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Assuming I'm more ethical than your client.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So, injecting yourself with donor red blood cells for fun and profit. Any other tricks up your sleeve?

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: Well, nothing much recently. I'm in town for a charity ride so it didn't matter if I won. The kids just needed to see me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So you go slower they see you longer. Let's say that our health could be affected by things we did before last Friday.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: Well... umm, I usually sleep in a hyperbaric chamber. I've been pumping up electrolytes with an IV drip and herbal supplements, amphetamines, and diuretics

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah yeah yeah yeah, but why would you be sick?

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: I know that doping has risks, I know that it's outside the rules, but I do what I have to to kick ass at my job. Don't you?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Dr House is a firm believer in good old-fashioned hard work.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This guy doesn't even get sick like a regular person. Instead of a list of symptoms and no cause, we have a list of possible causes for one symptom

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Is the symptom death?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Respiratory distress. And insanity doesn't cause it, I looked it up.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It's the doping. Injecting extra red cells boosts your endurance level, but it also thickens your blood. Thick blood equals clots equals respiratory distress

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not with a clean spiral chest CT

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Guy's sleeping in a hyperbaric chamber. Over-oxygenation can cause cell damage and if the cells in the lungs are damaged--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That'd cause pulmonary oedema which he doesn't have

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Supplements he's been taking contain yojimbo which can cause nerve paralysis

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Tox screen was normal. All the tests were normal. There's no clot, no oedema, and yet he still can't breathe, so there's something in here that we can't see.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Oh! Air.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Come to papa!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: This guy's been injecting himself how many times a day? All it'd take is one slip of the needle to cause an air embolus.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The air is keeping him from breathing air. Let's go with that for the irony. Get a VQ scan, check his veins for bubbles.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Xenon 133, it's just radioactive enough for us to track the air movement through your lungs

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: My accident on the news?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah, you made page of the week

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: Few more hours and cycling would be as popular as NASCAR

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We inject similar stuff into your blood so we can watch it circulate. Now, if you accidentally injected a bubble, we'll see you get air flow, but poor blood flow.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: I'm careful man

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: With all due respect, man, I doubt there's anything wrong with you that you didn't do to yourself

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: There's this kid in oncology, she's got a picture of Jeff above her bed.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Mickey Mantle was an alcoholic

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: At least he hit his own home runs. He didn't physically alter himself.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We take drugs to help us fall asleep, stay awake--

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We don't make careers out of who can stay awake the longest!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Really? Ever been to oh, I don't know, med school?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Er, guys? He plays a game for a living. Who cares? And you, you don't even like sports!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He's making millions of dollars ripping off fans

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Anyone who thinks they should pay a guy money because he can throw a ball really far or pedal really fast deserves to be ripped off

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Yeah, stupid stupid kids

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I've got an uncle, he can spit a cherry pit 50 yards. He's working part time at a lube shop! Life isn't fair!

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Maybe it is.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You were right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Now there were 3 wasted words.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: There is a bubble in his lung. We should do a Swan-Ganz catheterisation.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I love when you do both sides of the conversation. It's like white noise, it's very peaceful.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Is there a light somewhere that goes on when I have food?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Green for food, orange for beverages, red for impure thoughts. That bulb burns out every 2 weeks.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How's your biker?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Pumped an air bubble into a vein in his lung.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The things people do. Doping, Vicodin...

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hey! You're talking about me aren't you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm just trying to function. He's trying to win himself some little yellow jerseys. Uh oh.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Trouble in paradise, 2 o' clock

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Your 2 o' clock or my 2 o' clock?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: there.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: She looks perfectly happy. Obviously they huddled in the hall and worked up this circus act on the off-chance you'd be in here

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She was unbelievably pissy 3 hours ago

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Hmm! Pissy with you, happy with her husband. Yes there could only be one possible explanation

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: When she's angry, she gets sarcastic. When she's annoyed, she's funny, but when she's frustrated, she gets pissy

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yes, yes, I'm with you so far

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She's miserable with Mark because he's not me. So she's gotta make me not me, so she makes my professional life miserable, if I can't do my job--

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You really, really, need to get some--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh I get some "some" all the time, I always need to borrow "some" money

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: Hi James, Greg. Gotten to that paperwork?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I've been pissy.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: Pardon me?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I've been busy. When you save someone's life, they owe you forever.

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: You're right. Take Stacy. Oh wait, she'd probably just leave you all over again.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How's your recovery going? Gotten around to the small muscles yet?

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: It's not the size of the muscle, it’s where you get to put it.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: My goodness, it's like watching Oscar Wilde and Noel Coward in the third grade. Excuse us

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How awkward was that? What's he doing here anyway? He's got physio Tuesdays and Fridays.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Er, Mark is in group therapy for people coping with disability. He was thinking about developing a drug addiction but that would be stupid.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hey! Your you again!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Not going to make some joke about Mark being in therapy?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What's there to say? It’s only the responsible thing. I'm sure he's got a lot to deal with

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You're making me nervous

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: Everytime an athlete goes down you guys assume it's drugs. Look, the doctors say it's probably acid reflux. Yeah, look, call me tomorrow, there's a good chance he'll be released. Okay, bye bye so is this fixing him?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: If his acid reflux isn't worse than we thought, yeah

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: I got to be in Spain in 4 days

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Shouldn't be a problem

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: Great

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: If I can just find the little bugger, should be able to suck it out

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: My legs feel weak

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You're under mild sedation for the test, it'll wear off there it is

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Ah, got it.

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: Ooh, fantastic! I'll pack his things.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Not yet, I want to monitor him for a couple of hours, make sure he's ok. Give him time to sign a picture for me, maybe even a jersey?

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: To Dr Chase, I owe you everything?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Er, it doesn't have to be that personal.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: Ah, not too many Ebay shoppers named Dr Chase huh?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Still trying to unload the Barbara Walter spit cup.

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: Here you go

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Seriously, anything's fine.

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: Jeff?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You all right? Jeff! Can you swallow?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What makes a guy start drooling? Chase, were you wearing your short shorts?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Muscle fatigue in his neck and jaw. He's obviously got something worse than an air embolus.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Because... you don't drool from your lungs?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Maybe the problem is not the embolus itself. Maybe it's the treatment. Maybe you hit a nerve, literally.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The embolectomy was clean. His legs were tired too. I thought it was from the sedation but if not, means he's got something systemic.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Which means it would have nothing to do with the stunts he's been pulling

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Lupus, or polymyocitis. It explains the progressive muscle weakness

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It could be ALS

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He's too young for that

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Some type of muscular dystrophy?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He's too old for that

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So what would be just right, Goldilocks? Full blood workup, including ANA for lupus. And get a muscle biopsy; find out if we're talking myopathy or neuropathy. I'm late for my session

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Session?

utterance.speaker: Dr Harper
utterance.content: It's all a part of the process. You get angry, and then you get--

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: Yeah, right on schedule. So, when am I going to be done? I need to know 'cause I got plans to make. When can I safely book a game of squash? When am I going to stop being angry?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not today. I've come for the healing. Dr Harper, as you know, I err, I have a bum leg. What you don't know is, I'm upset about it. I need to talk.

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: You know House! You know we have a history!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You've been telling me for years that I should come by. Here I am. Hi guys

utterance.speaker: Dr Harper
utterance.content: Got a Thursday group.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Poker night.

utterance.speaker: Dr Harper
utterance.content: Monday morning?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Book club. Well look, if it's a problem, I'll just go deal with my rage privately.

utterance.speaker: Dr Harper
utterance.content: Wait. If you two could resolve this tension, you could really help each other.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm tired of fighting.

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: What? So either I say yes or I'm the jerk?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh god, I know that feeling.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I took the muscle specimen from Jeff's thigh. Figured that's where we'd have the best chance of finding something.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The most painful place to cut into.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I assume that's caffeine-free. Wouldn't want to be artificially boosting your performance.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Oh, don't start her up again.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Caffeine's legal.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: All about the rules, eh?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It's a bike race. A completely arbitrary set of rules that everyone complies with, for no other reason than that some committee says that they should.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Huh.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: But that's the point. That's what the game is.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So if you break an arbitrary rule, Cameron damns you to hell, but if you break a rule that actually has a reason that's designed to protect people, Cameron develops a crazy crush on you.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: House doesn't pretend to be some golden boy, he does it to help people, not to glorify himself.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So why don't you report Jeff to the biking authorities?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Umm, ethics.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well you wouldn't be doing it to glorify yourself, you'd just be trying to make a better world.

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: At least you can still get around on your own.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah I know, but you're starting to walk. You're going to get better.

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: You have a job, a way to be productive.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You have a wife, which gives greater meaning. Wife could make things harder too I suppose.

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: This isn't about Stacy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: When it happened to me, Stacy was great. She kept telling me not to rush it. I never believed her.

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: She means it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I know, but... Stacy... She shouldn't have to wait, right? And you know she feels it too. Needs more time at work, needs more satisfaction from work. She didn't get married to be a nursemaid. She wants a man.

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: How the hell could she have loved a manipulative son of a bitch like you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's an interesting question. Maybe she was attracted to different things in the two of us.

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: She left you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But why was she with me to begin with?

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: She made a mistake!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Maybe it's that simple. Or maybe she saw something in me, something that she doesn't get from you.

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: I'm not an ass!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Maybe she wanted an ass. She obviously did once.

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: Either he goes, or I go!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You think that's the kind of thing you can just turn off?

utterance.speaker: Mark
utterance.content: Get him out of here!

utterance.speaker: Dr Harper
utterance.content: Dr House, cancel your book group. You're coming on Mondays.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Here's my new theory. The drooling is another competitive edge. Nobody can drive behind him, the road gets slick, he's the only one not racing in the rain!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He can barely move his arms or legs.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Paralysis?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No, just general weakness.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Muscle biopsy is negative for polymyositis.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: And ALS. And muscular dystrophy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: ANA for lupus also negative.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Maybe his bike shorts are just on too tight.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: So, by your rationale, House shouldn't use a cane, he should just drag his bum leg around as God intended?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: House has a handicap; all he's aiming for is normality.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: And who decides what's normal? What if we find a drug that makes people live 20 years longer? Should we ban that because it's not normal?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Jeff doesn't want normal, he wants superpowers.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So why is he normal?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Oh god, you too?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He's shooting for extraordinary, so why is everything so ordinary? I mean this guy's breathing, drinking and injecting himself with everything he can find to amp up his body chemistry, and yet every test is normal. He's artificially raising his red blood count, so why isn't it raised?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Maybe his count is raised; maybe what's normal for us is out of whack for him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Can't slip anything by you.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well if that's true, then his white cells are up too, which would point to some kind of infection.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Muscle weakness, exhaustion? He could have encephalitis.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: That's kind of a long shot.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, but it's been over an hour since we poked the patient with something sharp so, get a lumbar puncture. And order broad spectrum antibiotics.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No, it's not about judging, it's just that on a dating service, you should post a photo.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I have to go.

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: I am so sorry to bother you.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No no, not a problem I was just... err... accounting.

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: I'm Jeff Forster's manager. He's been here a whole day, and it doesn't seem like we're any closer to a diagnosis.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Jeff Forster... a whole day, huh?

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: Uh huh, I was just wondering if I could help speed things up.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Your client's had a muscle biopsy, a full blood work-up, and he's scheduled for a lumbar puncture at 10am tomorrow.

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: Jeff is in the Lucas wing. If Mr Lucas showed up needing a lumbar puncture, would he have to wait until tomorrow?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Mr Lucas is dead.

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: Good, then there's an opening.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Jeff is used to doing whatever he has to do to be first doesn't he?

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: It’s been very lucrative for him. He feels it's important that he give something back I hear you've been raising funds for your nuclear medicine department or whatever.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: Thank you guys for working so late.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Glad to be here. The lumbar puncture will tell us what kind of infection you've got. In the meantime, we're administering antibiotics.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Do you like being a hero?

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: It's a living.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You don't feel a sense of responsibility? There's kids out there that worship you.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: When I was a rookie, on the tour, I got a letter from a guy in Wisconsin. He wanted me to send a note to his son, said he worshipped me. You know what worship means? I looked it up. It means to love, unquestioningly, and uncritically. So the kid doesn't even know me, but he loves me. Unquestioningly, and uncritically.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: So you decided to take advantage of that?

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: What should I have done? Dear Sir, I'm just a guy who rides a bike pretty good, you and your kid are out of your minds? My arm feels…feels funny...

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: His sats are dropping, he's in respiratory arrest.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Can't be, we fixed that!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Apparently not

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So glad we cured his respiratory arrest, freed him up to develop respiratory arrest.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: LP was negative for encephalitis.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The white count is still the same, but the red count's fallen to 29 percent.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What was my theory yesterday?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: That I screwed up the embolectomy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We'll get a chest X-ray to check.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I didn't screw up--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why would you be so petty, Chase? He's down a court. Either he's losing blood because you nicked something, or he's just not producing blood in which case we're talking acute anaemia combined with a muscular disorder.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Paraneoplastic syndrome?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Either you screwed up, or he's got cancer.

utterance.speaker: Patient
utterance.content: I think I should start smoking again.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You want a medical opinion supporting that decision?

utterance.speaker: Patient
utterance.content: The symptoms started as soon as I quit.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Symptoms meaning diarrhoea. A lot of diarrhoea.

utterance.speaker: Patient
utterance.content: Ten or twelve times a day, it's really embarrassing. I'm a flight attendant, and...

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, if you're upset, my hiccups are gone.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: You went to his group.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well you were the one who was all ‘Greg, you need to confront your feelings’.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: that was 5 years ago.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I've been pissy.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: Fine, you don't want help; does that mean nobody should get it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Mark's looking for help because... what? He’s resentful? Overwhelmed? I'm asking because I care.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: Not about him, you still want to jump me so you don't care who's married--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Look, I could get my rocks off anytime I want. What I don't seem to be able to do is my job without you hanging over my shoulder.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How many packs?

utterance.speaker: Patient
utterance.content: A bit over one a day but they were lights and I quit. You used to go out with her?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. What was I thinking? I'm talking about the gum you're chewing; you ever play smoking as an oral fixation. How many packs?

utterance.speaker: Patient
utterance.content: Six, maybe seven.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: I'm trying to protect you. Cuddy and I may be the only people stopping you from jumping off a cliff just to prove that you--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're pissy.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: Oh I am angry!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Pissy. You only get pissy when you're frustrated.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: Shut up!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ok, I'm wrong.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: This is unbelievably difficult for Mark, which you should know, which you should be able to summon up some level of empathy for.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right. The cripple boys. We should start a band.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: I have a good thing with Mark, we are handling this the best way we know how.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And none of this has anything to do with me?

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: No, nothing! Except that you can't, or won't just let it go! Let it go.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're being poisoned.

utterance.speaker: Patient
utterance.content: By gum?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sugarless gum uses sorbitol as a sweetener. We use sorbitol as a laxative.

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: This will tell you if he's got cancer in his blood?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: If he does, we'll see abnormal cells in the marrow.

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: How long will the test take?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'll get them in as soon as I can.

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: And if he doesn't have cancer, what else could it be?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It's possible some damage was done during one of the tests we gave him.

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: So either one of your doctors screwed up a simple procedure, or he's got cancer.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: We can't know anything for sure until the biopsy comes back.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It stings, I know.

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: No, he wants the tube out.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Can't do that, Jeff. If you want to say something you've got to write it down, okay?

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: Here.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: If it's cancer, it's possible. There's no way to know for sure.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Phone not working? One of the morgue attendants asked me to bring this to you

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Wonder why they're calling me.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah, me too actually. I was wondering why the Times was returning your call. You a doctor, or the bicycle police?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He's cheating. Shouldn't get away with it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Have you actually told them anything yet?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You worried about the precedent?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I'm worried about you.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You going to turn me in?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No. He's made a mistake, revealing the truth doesn't undo it.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Kids love him and he's not who they think he is. It's not right.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Who cares if he's what he says he is? Who the hell is? If love's based on lies, does that mean it's not a real feeling? Doesn't bring the same pleasure?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Are we still talking about the patient?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Have you... ever cheated? Well, I have. You want to punish him, good for you; but you can't do it without punishing the people who love him.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Is that how you justified lying to your wives?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I always told them.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well, he's negative for bleeds.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Congratulations, Chase. It's cancer. Clean him up and let Oncology have him, it's their party now.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He doesn't have cancer. Biopsy shows he's got pure red cell aplasia.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: There's no way PRCA could manifest so suddenly.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Unless it's drug-induced. He's lying about not being on EPO?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why would he lie?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: What does it matter?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: People lie for thousands of reasons, but there's always a reason.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Philosophically interesting, medically irrelevant.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Unless he's not lying.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You've got a leak. The Press is all over the Jeff Forster story.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: On the off-chance that one of you were stupid enough to call from your own office, I'm pulling your phone records, including your cell phones.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I assume if I point out the fact that you have no right to do that, you'll interpret that as a sign of guilt?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wilson's chatty. Plus he's got two ex-wives to support. You want me to tell him he's fired?

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: Until we figure out who's behind this, I'm sitting in with you guys. You have the ethics of a four-year-old; I'm going to treat you like one.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How am I supposed to practice medicine with a lawyer sitting on my shoulder?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Responsibly.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You know I can't do that!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Cameron.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I'm not the leak.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: Somebody once told me that everybody lies. Since you're the only people who know he has cancer--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He doesn't have cancer.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The point is, you're his medical team. He's threatening to sue.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why would Cameron leak cancer? How does cancer make the guy look bad? He's on EPO.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Your anaemia is caused by pure red cell aplasia. This is going to hurt, but we got to talk.

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: What the hell are you doing?!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He'll be fine. Sort of. I don't have time to watch him write out answers PRCA comes in two varieties, chronic and acute. Since it came on fast, you have the acute version.

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: He doesn't have cancer?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That's the good news. Bad news is, pants are on fire. Acute PRCA is caused by drugs, most commonly, EPO. Ready, and... action!

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: I haven't used EPO.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ok, this time, more anger! Remember, this guy's accusing you of cheating.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: I haven't used that stuff.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh mwah, I believed it. It was simple, it was pure. Did you believe it? I guess it's silly to cancel someone over the first audition. Why don't you do a reading?

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: Give me that! He doesn't do EPO!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hmm...what do you think? That was a different way to go but, I don't know, I just didn't buy it. Does she handle any of your injections?

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: You think I'm giving it to him? Test him!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Gee, that's a great idea. I sure hope that EPO's not one of those drugs that's undetectable after six hours. Hey you know what we can test for? Phone calls. Take her cell phone, push the redial button, even money says it'll be connected to the newspaper that leaked your cancer story Okay...

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: Okay, I should have told you. It's not just about the races, Jeff, it's about your image, okay? If you come back from cancer, those sponsors will be all over you. Okay so I messed up, okay, but I did NOT give you EPO!

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: That stuff could kill me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Come on, give her a break. She's only doing what she has to to advance her career. Don't you have that tattooed on your tushie?

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: I would never do anything to hurt you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Who're you going to believe? Manager you've trusted for years? I've been to college

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: You're fired.

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: Okay. You're basing this whole diagnosis, everything, on the idea that I was slipping him illegal drugs? You're going to kill him.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: If Dr House is so sure, why do you need to stay?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He's a very cautious man. Your breathing's better, let the prednisone do its job, get some sleep.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: His red blood cell count plummeted to 16 percent. He passed out, had to be rescusitated and still can't move his legs.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It's not possible. The drugs should be flushing out of his system.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Can't leave if they don't exist.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: But EPO use explains every one of his symptoms. He's been lying and cheating, and now it's coming back to bite him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The only problem with that theory is it's based on the assumption that the universe is a just place. If it were, then his poor manager wouldn't have been fired for no reason.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Lambert-Eaton.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: His chest was clear.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: So we run an electromyography test.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You're still not explaining the PRCA.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What's his red count now?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Had to give him a blood transfusion, he's back around 30.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He needed a transfusion?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well he was losing blood, so I thought maybe he needed blood.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Go forth and scan his neck.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: His neck?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Or repeat everything I say in question form.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She came into the clinic and yelled at me. Then she left. Then she came back and yelled some more.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Hmm. Yelling. That might be a clue.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I know what the yelling means, it's the coming and going I find interesting. It's not rational.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Anger's not rational?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Some anger is. She could have pulled me aside, screamed at me privately. Her beef is simple and well-founded. She was out of control.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You're having fun aren't you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She's in my face, I need to know why.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Professional reasons.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, why else?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Do you really think this is going to end well, for anyone?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: After this we'll scan some totally random body parts.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Fifty bucks says we find something.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Find what?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Don't have a clue. We on?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No way.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No. We'll find something.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We found a thymoma.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: How'd you know to look in his neck? Thymoma's usually present in the chest

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I knew it wasn't in his chest. All we've done since he checked in is look at his chest.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: All the more reason not to think--

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There are two types of PRCA. Acute comes on suddenly, chronic takes its time. We all thought Jeff's was acute because it happened right in front of us. What if it had been there for months? Maybe years?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: There's no way, it would have kept him from racing. With that kind of anaemia, he would have needed constant...

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Blood transfusions.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which he was getting in convenient blood-doping form.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He was treating himself without even knowing it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Up to half of patients with chronic PRCA have a thymoma. And up to half of patients with a thymoma… I’ve always wanted to do this.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: I'm not getting any better. Does that mean I'm--

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: Ow.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You are healed! Rise and walk.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: Are you insane?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: In the Bible, you just say "Yes Lord" and then, start right in on the praising.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: First you tell me I've got cancer, and then you tell me that my manager-- What did you do?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, what did you Lord. Thymoma is a tumour in the thymus gland. He's a bit of a wimp, but he hangs with the tough guys. PRCA and an auto-immune disease called myasthenia gravis. MG causes muscle fatigue, including respiratory problems and difficulty swallowing.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: It can hit you that fast?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Treatment for PRCA is blood transfusions, treatment for MG is hyperbaria. You were doing both as part of your regular freak show. When you took a break everything went to hell…which is not an uncommon reaction in Jersey.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: So... the whole thing with my manager..?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ooops. No, no EPO. This has nothing to do with anything you did. You can let her know she's in the clear.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: I could. Or, 10 percent of a Nike contract is a hell of a lot of cash.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You don't need your thymus. Take it out, everything else is manageable.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: Manageable. I thought you just cured me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nuh uh, this is just diagnostic. This just erases the symptoms of MG for five or six minutes Sometimes less. This is exactly why I created nurses. Cleanup on aisle three!

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: You've come to search my office; you should wait ten minutes I'll be out of your hair. Here, start with my purse just save me some mints. What do you want to know? My sex life with Mark? My guilt over crippling your damn leg? Or are you just here to gloat because you weren't the leak?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I want to apologise Maybe I've been punishing you for a little too long. And maybe you've been punishing me. If we're going to work together, I need to know - do you hate me? Or do you love me? Either way, I think we've got a problem.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: I hate you. And I love you. And I love Mark.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You don't hate him?

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So what do we do?

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: We deal with each other.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right. That plan's been working great so far.

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: It'll get better, it'll get easier.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: Stacy
utterance.content: I don't know, it's what my therapist tells me.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: In the professional cycling world we are subject to what seems like constant witch-hunts. But I want to thank Dr House and the excellent medical team here at Princeton Plainsboro. My hope is that this diagnosis will put to rest any rumours that I would ever--

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He needs blood transfusions every two weeks, which means he can dope all he wants. He's got a doctor's pass. It's medicinal. He got away with it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Mmmhmm, he cheated and won a game. Life's more complicated than who gets to the finish line first.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I fell in love with my husband's best friend. Near the end I was at the hospital every day, and Joe would come by after work. We'd go for walks and try to talk each other through it. We kind of clung on to each other.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: My wife wasn't dying, she wasn't even sick. Everything was fine. I met someone who... made me feel... funny. Good. And I didn't want to let that feeling go. What happened to you, how can anyone go through that alone? You can't control your emotions.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No. Just your actions.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You didn't do it, did you? You didn't sleep with him.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I couldn't have lived with myself.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You'd be surprised what you can live with.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hey, I need you to open that door.

utterance.speaker: Mopping guy
utterance.content: Not allowed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah er... I was having therapy in here today, and er, I left my cane.

utterance.speaker: Mopping guy
utterance.content: Sorry.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Dude! I'm crippled.
